reference.display_string: [Book] Valk, Ülo. 2001. The black gentleman : manifestations of the Devil in Estonian folk religion (FF Communications). Helsinki: Suomalainen Tiedeakatemia.

annotation:
The Red Smithy is the name of a pub in Nibe. Although Tang Kristensen's annotation is very short, one can surmise that Jens told a story of the devil at the pub. The devil was probably dressed as a gentleman (Välk 2001). In many stories, the devil arrives at the pub to play cards; when he is recognized, a person at the pub sends for a wise minister or, as in this case, a dean (proust), a person slightly higher up in the church hierarchy. 

     Tang Kristensen did not publish this abbreviated account, likely because he had not recorded the story.
danish_manuscript:
Fanden i den røde Smeddi. Provsten i Nibe
var der at drive ham væk. Værtshus v. Nibe.
english_manuscript: The devil in the Red Smithy. The dean from Nibe had gone there to drive him out. At the pub in Nibe.
english_publication: Unpublished version reads: The devil in the Red Smithy. The dean from Nibe had gone there to drive him out. At the pub in Nibe.
